title: CBC Radio
text:
The federal election campaign is officially underway and there's a lot to know between now and voting day.

To keep you up to date as Oct. 21 nears, several CBC podcasts and on-demand radio programs are delivering the facts and insight you need.

Rosie takes stock of each party’s position out of the gate. What’s at stake for each leader — and what would success look like? And Elamin wants to talk about the elephants in the room. How does each leader talk about the things they’d rather not talk about? 24:19

Party Lines is a political primer for every kind of concerned citizen. Each episode will take you beyond the talking points and provide the insights you need to understand the upcoming federal election.

This podcast is co-hosted by two independent thinkers with their own kind of cred — Rosemary Barton of The National and Elamin Abdelmahmoud of BuzzFeed News. New episodes will come out every Thursday in the lead up to the vote.

In Please Explain, voters come on Front Burner to ask their biggest questions about the election. First up: Marieke Walsh from the Globe and Mail explains the party platforms on climate change, and how the carbon tax is doing for Canada. 27:36

Front Burner is a daily news podcast that connects you to the big stories of the day. Every weekday, award-winning investigative journalist Jayme Poisson leads you deep into the narratives shaping Canada and the world with curiosity and an open mind.

For the federal election, they're launching two new series: a weekly panel featuring some of the country's top political minds as well as a new and recurring segment called Please Explain, which invites listeners onto the show in search of answers for their election-related questions.

Candidates hit the hustings on the first day of the 2019 Federal election, on Sept. 11, 2019. Clockwise from top left: Conservative leader Andrew Scheer, People's Party leader Maxime Bernier, Liberal leader Justin Trudeau, NDP leader Jagmeet Singh, Green Party leader Elizabeth May and Bloc Quebecois leader Yves-François Blanchet. (Paul Chiasson/The Canadian Press (CP), Evan Mitsui/CBC, Sean Kilpatrick/CP, Chad Hipolito/CP, Adrian Wyld/CP)

On this Sunday edition of the Pollcast, host Éric Grenier and Elise von Scheel take a look at the early polls in this campaign — and chat about the undecided and the fence-sitter voters. 8:11

Éric Grenier, CBC's polls analyst, explores the world of political polls, their influence on the media and the trends they suggest. This weekly program takes a deep dive into the world of politics, elections and public opinion in conversations with journalists, decision makers and the pollsters tapping into what the country is thinking.

How did the parties fare in the election kickoff? And what tone did it set for the next five weeks? Vassy Kapelos, host of Power and Politics, and Joel Denis Bellavance, parliamentary bureau chief for La Presse, join Chris Hall for a chat. 5:43

The House with Chris Hall takes you behind the scenes in the world of Canadian politics. By adding colour, context and original reporting, this weekly program takes House of Commons proceedings from "boring" to enticing.

The federal leaders squared off in the first debate of the election campaign...minus Justin Trudeau. Why did the Liberal leader choose to skip this one? And how did the other leaders do? Chantal Hébert, Andrew Coyne and Althia Raj join Rosemary Barton for a post-debate analysis. 12:28

The National's Rosemary Barton tackles the major political stories of the week with Canada's leading political journalists on At Issue. This is the podcast that helps answer the "why" behind the moves and decisions of your elected officials.

Green Party leader Elizabeth May, right, NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh, centre, Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer, second left and moderator Paul Wells, left, finish the Maclean's/Citytv National Leaders Debate in Toronto during week one of the campaign. (Frank Gunn/The Canadian Press)

Liberal leader Justin Trudeau visited Gov. Gen. Julie Payette Wednesday, asking her to dissolve Parliament so Canadians can go to the polls on Oct. 21. We speak to a panel of former MPs about what to expect from the campaign ahead. 25:16

CBC Radio's flagship daily current affairs show The Current holds the powerful to account and explores the surprising twists and turns of the always-evolving news landscape.

Through candid interviews and fresh insight, interim host Laura Lynch brings you new angles on the issues of the day. Each Wednesday, the program features a 30-minute-long segment with a rotating roster of panellists who unpack the national political landscape from differing perspectives.

Candidates Candice Bergen, Angella MacEwan, Marco Mendicino and Lorraine Rekmans debate how parties are dealing with candidate controversies, then the Power Panel weighs in. Plus, Kathleen Petty and Paddy Daly join Éric Grenier to talk about what's driving votes in Alberta and N.L. 43:37

Every weekday, host Vassy Kapelos guides Canadians through the country's political news, with a regular cast of political panellists and the continuously unfolding drama of the Canadian political scene.
description: The federal election campaign is officially underway. Here are the CBC radio shows and podcasts working to get you ready for voting day.
